description.overview: 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), commonly known as ecstasy or molly, is an empathogen-entactogen that produces feelings of emotional openness, empathy, and euphoria. It's one of the most popular recreational drugs worldwide, particularly in dance and festival settings.
description.origins: First synthesized by Merck pharmaceutical company in 1912, MDMA remained obscure until the 1970s when chemist Alexander Shulgin resynthesized it and introduced it to psychotherapists. It gained popularity as a therapeutic tool before becoming a Schedule I controlled substance in 1985.
description.uses: Originally explored for marriage counseling and PTSD treatment in psychotherapy. Currently used recreationally for its prosocial effects, emotional warmth, and sensory enhancement. FDA-approved clinical trials are ongoing for PTSD-assisted therapy with promising results.
description.dangers: Neurotoxicity concerns with frequent use, especially at high doses or elevated body temperatures. Risk of hyperthermia, hyponatremia (water intoxication), serotonin syndrome. Often adulterated with methamphetamine, MDA, cathinones, or other stimulants. Increasing fentanyl contamination in pressed pills. Can cause short-term memory issues, depression, and anxiety in the days following use ('comedown').

scientific_papers.title: MDMA-assisted therapy for severe PTSD: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 study
scientific_papers.summary: MAPS Phase 3 trial showing 67% of participants no longer met PTSD criteria after MDMA-assisted therapy

scientific_papers.title: The pharmacology and clinical pharmacology of 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, ecstasy)
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of MDMA pharmacology, metabolism, and toxicology

scientific_papers.title: MDMA (Ecstasy): a review of its harms and classification under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971
scientific_papers.authors: Nutt D, King LA, Saulsbury W, Blakemore C
scientific_papers.summary: Evidence-based harm assessment placing MDMA lower than alcohol and tobacco

scientific_papers.title: Neurotoxicity of amphetamines and its metabolites
scientific_papers.summary: Review of neurotoxicity mechanisms and risk factors for MDMA-induced neurotoxicity

notes: Use multiple reagents; lighting/timing matter.

description.overview: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a powerful hallucinogenic drug that profoundly alters perception, mood, and thought. Known for producing vivid visual hallucinations, synesthesia, and mystical experiences, LSD is one of the most potent psychoactive substances known, active at microgram doses.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1938 by Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann at Sandoz Laboratories while researching ergot alkaloids. Its psychedelic properties were discovered accidentally in 1943 when Hofmann absorbed a small amount through his skin. Widely used in psychiatric research in the 1950s-60s before being scheduled in 1968.
description.uses: Historically used in psychotherapy for treating alcoholism, anxiety, and depression. Currently being researched for treatment of PTSD, anxiety, depression, and cluster headaches. Recreationally used for introspection, creativity enhancement, and transcendent experiences. Microdosing (sub-perceptual doses) popular for cognitive enhancement.
description.dangers: Psychological risks include 'bad trips,' anxiety, paranoia, and exacerbation of underlying mental health conditions. Rare but serious risk of persistent perceptual changes (HPPD). No physical addiction or toxicity, but psychologically intense. Primary danger is NBOMe compounds sold as LSD—these can be fatal and taste bitter/metallic. Real LSD is tasteless and causes tongue numbness only from ink/paper.

scientific_papers.title: LSD-assisted psychotherapy for anxiety associated with a life-threatening disease: a qualitative study
scientific_papers.journal: Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease
scientific_papers.summary: First controlled study in 40 years showing LSD-assisted therapy reduced anxiety in terminal illness patients

scientific_papers.title: Acute, subacute and long-term subjective effects of psilocybin in healthy humans: a pooled analysis of experimental studies
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive safety analysis showing classical psychedelics have low toxicity and adverse event rates

scientific_papers.title: Neural correlates of the LSD experience revealed by multimodal neuroimaging
scientific_papers.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
scientific_papers.summary: Neuroimaging study revealing how LSD affects brain connectivity and consciousness

uv_light.summary: Blotter paper often fluoresces (optical brighteners); not diagnostic of LSD.

taste.summary: Avoid taste-testing; unreliable and risky (NBOMe risk).

description.overview: 1-Propionyl-lysergic acid diethylamide (1P-LSD) is a psychedelic lysergamide and prodrug of LSD. Produces effects nearly identical to LSD after metabolizing in the body. Popular research chemical due to legal status in some countries where LSD is banned. Active dose 100-150mcg, duration 8-12 hours. Indistinguishable from LSD in effects.
description.origins: First synthesized in 2015 by unknown chemist. Appeared on research chemical market as legal alternative to LSD in countries where LSD is Schedule I. Rapidly gained popularity due to identical effects and easier legal access. Metabolizes to LSD in the body—essentially LSD with a propionyl group attached. Scheduled in some countries but remains legal gray area in others.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Identical effects to LSD—visual hallucinations, altered perception, mystical experiences. Microdosing popular (10-20mcg doses). Typical dose 100-150mcg on blotter paper. Duration 8-12 hours. Used interchangeably with LSD by many users. Some prefer it due to legal status in certain jurisdictions. Research: Tool for studying psychedelics in countries where LSD research restricted.
description.dangers: Same psychological risks as LSD: bad trips, anxiety, HPPD (rare), triggering latent mental illness. Very safe physiologically—no lethal dose, no organ toxicity. Legal ambiguity: may be prosecuted as LSD analogue under analogue acts. Quality varies—some blotter contains other substances. Should still use Ehrlich reagent to confirm indole (will react same as LSD). Dosing more consistent than street LSD due to research chemical market quality control. Main risk is unexpected intensity if user assumes it's weaker than LSD (it's not).

scientific_papers.title: Psychedelic N-benzyl-phenethylamine derivatives: a chemical class of interest
scientific_papers.summary: Overview of lysergamide analogues including 1P-LSD as LSD prodrugs

notes: LSD prodrug—metabolizes to LSD. Ehrlich reacts same as LSD (purple). Effects identical to LSD. Legal in some jurisdictions.

description.overview: 1-Acetyl-LSD (ALD-52) is a psychedelic lysergamide and LSD prodrug. Nearly identical effects to LSD after metabolizing. Famous as allegedly being the active compound in 1960s 'Orange Sunshine' LSD. Duration 6-10 hours, dose 100-150mcg. Some users report smoother, less anxious experience than LSD.
description.origins: Synthesized by Albert Hofmann (LSD's inventor) in 1950s but not widely publicized. Became famous in 1960s when Tim Scully and Nick Sand were arrested—they claimed their 'Orange Sunshine' LSD was actually ALD-52 (then legal). Court rejected this defense. Reappeared on research chemical market in 2010s. Metabolizes to LSD in body, making them functionally identical.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Effects virtually identical to LSD—visual hallucinations, altered perception, mystical experiences. Some users claim slightly gentler, warmer experience than LSD. Typical dose 100-150mcg. Duration 6-10 hours (slightly shorter than LSD for some). Popular in research chemical community. Microdosing applications similar to LSD.
description.dangers: Same risks as LSD: psychological only—bad trips, anxiety, potential HPPD, triggering latent mental illness. Physiologically very safe. Legal gray area: prosecutable as LSD analogue in many countries. Quality inconsistent in research chemical market. Should test with Ehrlich to confirm indole (reacts same as LSD). Main danger is legal prosecution rather than pharmacological toxicity. Set and setting crucial as with all psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: The chemistry continues: structure elucidation and synthesis of new psychoactive substances
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of lysergamide analogues including ALD-52 (1-acetyl-LSD)

notes: LSD prodrug. Famous 1960s 'Orange Sunshine' possibly ALD-52. Ehrlich reacts like LSD. Virtually identical effects.

description.overview: 6-Allyl-6-nor-LSD (AL-LAD) is a psychedelic lysergamide similar to LSD but with distinct characteristics. Known for being 'lighter,' shorter duration (6-8 hours), more visual, and less headspace-heavy than LSD. Popular as gentler alternative. Typical dose 150-300mcg (slightly less potent than LSD).
description.origins: First synthesized by Alexander Shulgin and David Nichols in 1970s-80s but not widely known. Documented in TiHKAL #1. Appeared on research chemical market around 2013. Gained popularity as more recreational, less intense alternative to LSD. Shorter duration and lighter headspace make it appealing for social settings. Scheduled in some countries.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Visual hallucinations (often described as more colorful than LSD), euphoria, lighter mental effects than LSD. Popular at music festivals due to shorter duration and manageable headspace. Typical dose 150-300mcg. Duration 6-8 hours (shorter than LSD). Some users prefer AL-LAD for recreational/party settings versus LSD for deeper introspection. Less likely to cause thought loops or anxiety than LSD.
description.dangers: Similar psychological risks to LSD but generally milder: potential for bad trips (less common), anxiety, triggering mental health issues. Physiologically safe. Dosing confusion: less potent than LSD per mcg—users need higher doses. Often sold at 150mcg tabs vs LSD's 100mcg. Taking 'one tab' of each produces different intensity. Quality varies in research chemical market. Legal gray area. Should still test with Ehrlich. Generally considered one of the safest, most forgiving psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: AL-LAD: Allyl-nor-LSD synthesis and effects
scientific_papers.summary: Original documentation in TiHKAL #1, noting lighter effects than LSD

notes: Lighter than LSD. Shorter duration (6-8 hours). More visual, less headspace. Dose 150-300mcg. TiHKAL #1. Popular recreational alternative.

description.overview: 6-Ethyl-6-nor-LSD (ETH-LAD) is a potent psychedelic lysergamide, more powerful than LSD per microgram. Known for extremely intense visuals, strong body load, and powerful mental effects. Duration 8-12 hours. Typical dose 40-100mcg (about 2x more potent than LSD). Demanding and intense experience.
description.origins: First synthesized by Alexander Shulgin and documented in TiHKAL #2. Less well-known than AL-LAD historically. Appeared on research chemical market in 2010s. Gained reputation for being significantly more intense and visual than LSD. Some users report it's the most visually intense lysergamide. Less popular than AL-LAD or 1P-LSD due to intensity and body load.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Extremely intense visual hallucinations, powerful mental effects, significant body sensations. Typical dose 40-100mcg (more potent than LSD). Duration 8-12 hours. Often described as 'LSD on steroids' in terms of visuals. Less forgiving than LSD—requires experience and careful set/setting. Some psychonauts seek it specifically for intense visual experiences. Not recommended for beginners.
description.dangers: Significantly more intense than LSD—higher risk of overwhelming experiences and bad trips. Strong body load including vasoconstriction, nausea, muscle tension. Powerful mental effects can cause anxiety, paranoia, thought loops. Dose-sensitive: 40mcg difference can dramatically change experience. Often mis-dosed—sold at doses too high for most users. Physically safe but psychologically demanding. Contraindicated for those with anxiety or family history of mental illness. Requires very careful dosing and preparation.

scientific_papers.title: ETH-LAD: Ethyl-nor-LSD synthesis and potency
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation in TiHKAL #2, noting higher potency and intensity than LSD

notes: More potent than LSD (40-100mcg). Extremely intense visuals. Strong body load. TiHKAL #2. Not for beginners. Demanding experience.

description.overview: Lysergic acid 2,4-dimethylazetidide (LSZ, also called Lambda) is a psychedelic lysergamide similar to LSD in effects and potency. Duration 8-10 hours, dose 100-200mcg. Less researched than other lysergamides but reports suggest near-identical experience to LSD. Appeared briefly on research chemical market.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin and documented in TiHKAL #31. Not well-studied historically. Appeared on research chemical market around 2012-2013 but never gained widespread popularity. Less available than 1P-LSD or AL-LAD. Some users report it's virtually indistinguishable from LSD. Production and availability have been inconsistent.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Effects very similar to LSD—visual hallucinations, altered perception, introspection. Typical dose 100-200mcg. Duration 8-10 hours. Less well-known and less available than other lysergamides. Some users specifically sought it during brief availability period. Reports suggest it may be slightly less potent than LSD but qualitatively similar. Rarely discussed due to limited availability.
description.dangers: Same psychological risks as LSD: bad trips, anxiety, triggering mental health conditions. Physiologically safe based on structural similarity to LSD. Less research than other lysergamides means fewer experience reports—dosing guidelines less certain. Quality highly variable due to limited production. Legal gray area. Should test with Ehrlich. Main issue is scarcity and lack of consistent information rather than inherent danger. Generally considered similar safety profile to LSD.

scientific_papers.title: LSZ: Lambda lysergamide synthesis
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation in TiHKAL #31, similar structure and effects to LSD

notes: Similar to LSD in effects (100-200mcg). Duration 8-10 hours. TiHKAL #31. Less available than other lysergamides. Limited research.

description.overview: Cocaine is a powerful stimulant drug extracted from coca plant leaves, producing intense euphoria, increased energy, and heightened alertness. One of the most addictive substances known, cocaine has profound effects on the brain's reward system and cardiovascular system.
description.origins: Indigenous peoples of South America have chewed coca leaves for thousands of years. Pure cocaine was first isolated in 1859 and became widely used in medicine and consumer products (including Coca-Cola) before its addictive properties were understood. Criminalized in most countries by the 1920s.
description.uses: Historically used as a local anesthetic in eye, nose, and throat surgeries (still used rarely for this purpose). Recreationally used for euphoria, confidence, and energy. No accepted medical use for systemic effects due to high addiction potential and cardiovascular risks.
description.dangers: Highly addictive with severe cardiovascular risks including heart attack, stroke, and arrhythmias. Nasal damage from snorting, lung damage from smoking crack. Often cut with levamisole (causes immune system damage), phenacetin (carcinogenic), and increasingly fentanyl (lethal). Overdose can cause seizures, hyperthermia, and cardiac arrest. Psychological dependence develops rapidly.

scientific_papers.title: Cardiovascular toxicity of cocaine: an overview
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of cocaine's cardiovascular effects including myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and sudden death

scientific_papers.title: Levamisole contamination: a potential risk for all cocaine users
scientific_papers.summary: Study on levamisole adulterant causing agranulocytosis and necrotic skin lesions in cocaine users

scientific_papers.title: Cocaine use and risk of myocardial infarction and stroke: systematic review and meta-analysis
scientific_papers.summary: Meta-analysis showing cocaine use significantly increases risk of heart attack and stroke

notes: Cocaine often shows minimal/no reaction with common reagents. Use multiple tests; fentanyl strips recommended.

description.overview: Methamphetamine (meth, crystal, ice) is an extremely potent central nervous system stimulant with high abuse potential. It produces intense euphoria, increased energy, and focus, but is notorious for its destructive physical and psychological effects with chronic use.
description.origins: First synthesized in Japan in 1919 from ephedrine. Used by military forces in WWII to enhance soldier alertness. Became popular in 1960s biker culture and later in the 1990s with improved synthesis methods. The 'Breaking Bad' era saw Mexican cartel production dominate the market.
description.uses: Prescription methamphetamine (Desoxyn) exists for ADHD and severe obesity but is rarely prescribed. Recreationally used for euphoria, energy, focus, and appetite suppression. Popular in club scenes, among long-haul drivers, and for sexual enhancement (chemsex).
description.dangers: Severe neurotoxicity with repeated use, causing permanent damage to dopamine and serotonin systems. 'Meth mouth' (severe dental decay), skin sores from compulsive picking, extreme weight loss, psychosis, paranoia, and violent behavior. Cardiovascular strain can cause heart attack and stroke. Often cut with MSM, ISO, or N-Iso (look identical). Sleep deprivation from binges causes hallucinations and psychotic breaks. Highly addictive with devastating social consequences.

scientific_papers.title: Methamphetamine neurotoxicity: dissociation of striatal dopamine terminal damage from parietal cortical cell body injury
scientific_papers.summary: Foundational study on methamphetamine-induced neurotoxicity and dopamine system damage

scientific_papers.title: Methamphetamine-associated psychosis
scientific_papers.summary: Review of meth-induced psychosis, prevalence, and treatment strategies

scientific_papers.title: The Matrix Model for methamphetamine addiction: evidence-based strategies
scientific_papers.summary: Evidence-based treatment protocol for methamphetamine addiction

notes: Simon's test distinguishes meth (no reaction) from MDMA (blue). Use multiple reagents.

description.overview: 3,4-Methylenedioxyamphetamine (MDA), known as 'sass' or 'the love drug,' is the parent compound of MDMA and produces similar empathogenic effects but with more pronounced psychedelic qualities. Often sold as or confused with MDMA, MDA has a longer duration and more intense visual effects.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1910, predating MDMA by decades. Used experimentally in psychotherapy in the 1960s-70s before MDMA became popular. Nicknamed 'the love drug' in the 1960s counterculture. Became Schedule I in 1970. Currently resurging as MDMA alternative or adulterant in pressed pills.
description.uses: Historically explored in psychotherapy for emotional processing and couples therapy. Recreationally used for empathogenic and mild psychedelic effects at music events and festivals. Some users prefer MDA's more 'trippy' character versus MDMA's pure empathy. Often unintentionally consumed when sold as MDMA.
description.dangers: Similar neurotoxicity concerns as MDMA, possibly greater. Higher body temperature elevation risk (hyperthermia). More prone to causing confusion and anxiety than MDMA due to psychedelic effects. Often found as MDMA adulterant or sold as 'MDMA' in pressed pills. Simon's reagent shows NO reaction (primary amine vs MDMA's secondary amine)—key distinction. Longer duration (6-8 hours) can lead to dehydration and exhaustion. Same risks: serotonin syndrome, hyponatremia, comedown depression.

scientific_papers.title: Comparative neurotoxicity of MDMA and MDA: a review
scientific_papers.summary: Comparative study showing MDA may have greater neurotoxicity than MDMA

scientific_papers.title: Chemistry and pharmacology of MDA and MDMA
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive report on MDA pharmacology and subjective effects by Alexander Shulgin

notes: Similar to MDMA but Simon's shows no reaction (MDA is primary amine, MDMA is secondary).

description.overview: Amphetamine (alpha-methylphenethylamine) is a central nervous system stimulant used medically to treat ADHD and narcolepsy. Racemic mixture or pure dextroamphetamine (d-amphetamine). Main component of Adderall (mixed amphetamine salts). Produces increased focus, energy, wakefulness, and euphoria. Commonly diverted for academic performance enhancement and recreational use. Street name 'speed.' Less potent than methamphetamine but similar effects. Widely prescribed and widely abused.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1887 by Romanian chemist Lazăr Edeleanu but effects not recognized. Rediscovered in 1920s. Benzedrine inhaler (racemic amphetamine) marketed 1933 for nasal congestion—users discovered stimulant effects. Widely used by military in WWII (both Allied and Axis forces) to combat fatigue. Became popular in 1950s-60s for weight loss and energy. Scheduled as controlled substance 1971. Adderall (mixed amphetamine salts) introduced 1996 for ADHD. Now Schedule II in US. Street 'speed' paste common in Europe; diverted Adderall common in US.
description.uses: Medical: ADHD treatment (Adderall, Dexedrine), narcolepsy, treatment-resistant depression (off-label). Improves focus, reduces hyperactivity and impulsivity in ADHD. Typical therapeutic dose 5-40mg daily. Recreational/Academic: Cognitive enhancement ('smart drug'), studying aid, increased energy and focus, euphoria, weight loss. Popular among college students during exams ('Adderall abuse'). Street speed (paste or powder) snorted or taken orally. Typical recreational dose 10-50mg. Duration 4-6 hours (immediate release) or 8-12 hours (extended release).
description.dangers: Cardiovascular risks: increased heart rate and blood pressure, risk of heart attack/stroke especially with pre-existing conditions. Abuse potential significant—tolerance and psychological dependence develop. Neurotoxicity at high doses (dopamine depletion). Psychosis, paranoia, hallucinations with chronic high-dose use. Appetite suppression leads to malnutrition with chronic use. Insomnia, anxiety, irritability. Compulsive behaviors (picking skin, repetitive tasks). Severe comedown: fatigue, depression, cognitive impairment. Withdrawal: extreme fatigue, depression, increased appetite, sleeping for days. IV use carries infection risks. Nasal damage from snorting. Counterfeit Adderall pills may contain methamphetamine or other substances. Mixing with alcohol or other stimulants dangerous.

scientific_papers.title: Amphetamine for ADHD: Efficacy and safety
scientific_papers.summary: Review of amphetamine's therapeutic efficacy and safety profile in ADHD treatment

scientific_papers.title: Cognitive enhancement with stimulants: Systematic review
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of amphetamine use for cognitive enhancement in healthy individuals

scientific_papers.title: Amphetamine abuse among college students
scientific_papers.summary: Survey study documenting widespread amphetamine misuse in academic settings

testing.alt: NO blue color (primary amine—only secondary amines like MDMA turn blue)

notes: Speed, Adderall. Base stimulant—similar to methamphetamine but less potent. Reagent tests CANNOT reliably distinguish amphetamine from methamphetamine (both orange with Marquis, no Simon's blue). Both are primary amines. Lab testing (GC/MS) required for definitive distinction. Pharmaceutical Adderall pills should match pill ID databases. Street 'speed' paste (common in Europe) is often amphetamine sulfate. Counterfeit Adderall may contain meth or other substances—test pressed pills.

meth_distinction.summary: Reagent tests cannot distinguish amphetamine from methamphetamine. Both give orange Marquis, no Simon's blue. Need lab testing (GC/MS) for definitive ID. Effects: Meth more potent, longer duration, more euphoric.

description.overview: 2C-B (4-Bromo-2,5-dimethoxyphenethylamine) is a synthetic psychedelic that combines visual hallucinations with empathogenic effects, often described as a hybrid between MDMA and LSD. Known for vivid, colorful visuals and emotional warmth at moderate doses. Highly dose-sensitive with effects varying dramatically by just a few milligrams.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1974 by Alexander Shulgin, who explored its effects in his book 'PiHKAL' (Phenethylamines I Have Known And Loved). Initially marketed in the 1980s as aphrodisiac 'Nexus' or 'Erox' before becoming scheduled. Gained popularity in European club scenes in 1990s-2000s. Now Schedule I in most countries but still widely available.
description.uses: Briefly explored as psychotherapy adjunct in 1980s before scheduling. Recreationally used for colorful visual hallucinations, enhanced music appreciation, tactile sensitivity, and emotional openness. Popular at festivals and clubs as 'party psychedelic'—more manageable than LSD. Some report aphrodisiac effects. Typical dose 15-25mg (highly dose-sensitive).
description.dangers: Extreme dose sensitivity: 5mg difference can dramatically change experience intensity. Uncomfortable body load at higher doses (nausea, tension, vasoconstriction). 'Nexus flip' (combining with MDMA) popular but increases risks. Often sold as ecstasy pills or mislabeled. Can cause anxiety or panic at unexpected high doses. Reagent test shows distinctive yellow-green (similar to other 2C-x compounds). Physical effects include increased heart rate and blood pressure. Bad trips possible especially in unsafe settings. Contraindicated with cardiovascular conditions.

scientific_papers.title: Pharmacology of 2C-B: a review
scientific_papers.summary: Original synthesis and detailed pharmacology report by Alexander Shulgin, including dosage and effects

scientific_papers.title: Acute effects of 2C-B on neuropsychological performance
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical study on cognitive and perceptual effects of 2C-B in controlled setting

scientific_papers.title: The 2C-phenethylamines: pharmacology, toxicology, and use
scientific_papers.summary: Review of the 2C-x family including 2C-B pharmacology, toxicity, and clinical presentation

notes: Distinctive yellow-green with Marquis/Mecke. Often confused with other 2C-x compounds.

description.overview: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that causes a sense of detachment from one's body and environment. Known for producing 'k-holes' (profound dissociative states), dream-like experiences, and analgesia. It has a remarkable safety profile compared to other anesthetics and is experiencing a renaissance as a depression treatment.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1962 by Calvin Stevens at Parke-Davis as a safer alternative to PCP for anesthesia. Approved for medical use in 1970. Widely used in Vietnam War as battlefield anesthetic. Became popular in rave/club scenes in the 1990s. Recently FDA-approved as esketamine (Spravato) nasal spray for treatment-resistant depression.
description.uses: Medical: WHO Essential Medicine for anesthesia, especially in emergency/field medicine and pediatrics. Pain management, sedation, and recently for treatment-resistant depression. Veterinary medicine (common horse tranquilizer stereotype). Recreational: Dissociative experiences, psychedelic exploration, club/rave scenes. Therapeutic: Psychedelic-assisted therapy for depression, PTSD, anxiety, and addiction showing promising results.
description.dangers: Bladder damage (ulcerative cystitis) with chronic heavy use—can become severe and irreversible. Respiratory depression when combined with other depressants (alcohol, opioids, benzodiazepines). Risk of injury during dissociation due to impaired coordination and pain perception. Psychological dependence possible. 'K-holes' can be psychologically distressing for unprepared users. Cognitive impairment with chronic use. Often cut with synthetic cathinones or other dissociatives (2-FDCK, DCK). Street ketamine purity highly variable.

scientific_papers.title: Ketamine for treatment-resistant depression: the first decade of progress
scientific_papers.summary: Review of breakthrough ketamine research showing rapid antidepressant effects in treatment-resistant depression

scientific_papers.title: Ketamine-induced ulcerative cystitis: a new clinical entity
scientific_papers.summary: First comprehensive report on ketamine-induced bladder damage in chronic recreational users

scientific_papers.title: The use of ketamine as an antidepressant: a systematic review and meta-analysis
scientific_papers.summary: Meta-analysis confirming ketamine's rapid antidepressant effects and safety profile in clinical settings

notes: Ketamine shows minimal reaction with most reagents. Specialized tests (Morris) available.

description.overview: Psilocybin is a naturally occurring psychedelic compound found in over 200 species of mushrooms ('magic mushrooms' or 'shrooms'). It produces profound alterations in perception, mood, thought, and sense of self. Psilocybin is considered one of the safest psychoactive substances with minimal toxicity and no addiction potential.
description.origins: Used in indigenous Mesoamerican spiritual and healing ceremonies for thousands of years. First isolated from Psilocybe mushrooms by Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann (who also discovered LSD) in 1958. Popularized in Western culture by R. Gordon Wasson's 1957 Life Magazine article. Scheduled in 1970 despite therapeutic research. Recently decriminalized or legalized in several US cities and states.
description.uses: Traditional: Spiritual ceremonies, divination, healing rituals in indigenous cultures. Current research: Treatment for depression, anxiety (especially end-of-life), PTSD, addiction (smoking, alcohol), cluster headaches, and OCD with breakthrough results. Recreational: Introspection, nature connection, creative insights, mystical experiences. Microdosing: Sub-perceptual doses for mood, creativity, and focus enhancement.
description.dangers: Physiologically very safe—no lethal dose established, no organ toxicity. Primary risks are psychological: 'bad trips' with anxiety, paranoia, or terrifying experiences, especially in unsafe settings or high doses. Can trigger latent mental health conditions or exacerbate existing ones. HPPD (flashbacks) rare but possible. Mushroom misidentification can be fatal—only consume from trusted sources or expert identification. No physical addiction but psychological attachment possible. Set and setting crucial for positive experiences. Contraindicated with certain mental health conditions (schizophrenia, bipolar).

scientific_papers.title: Psilocybin produces substantial and sustained decreases in depression and anxiety in patients with life-threatening cancer
scientific_papers.summary: Landmark trial showing single psilocybin dose reduced depression/anxiety in cancer patients for 6+ months

scientific_papers.title: Psilocybin for treatment-resistant depression: fMRI-measured brain mechanisms
scientific_papers.summary: Study showing psilocybin's antidepressant effects and brain mechanism via amygdala reactivity changes

scientific_papers.title: Psilocybin-occasioned mystical experiences in the treatment of tobacco addiction
scientific_papers.summary: Study showing 80% smoking cessation rate at 6-month follow-up after psilocybin-assisted therapy

scientific_papers.title: The safety and efficacy of psychedelic-assisted therapies: a review
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive safety review showing psilocybin has excellent safety profile in controlled settings

notes: Ehrlich for indole group confirmation. Whole mushrooms: test cap/stem separately if possible.

description.overview: Fentanyl is an extremely potent synthetic opioid, approximately 50-100 times stronger than morphine and 30-50 times stronger than heroin. Originally developed for pain management and anesthesia, it has become a major driver of overdose deaths when illicitly manufactured and mixed into other drugs without users' knowledge.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1959 by Belgian physician Paul Janssen as a surgical analgesic. Introduced medically in the 1960s for anesthesia and chronic pain management via patches and lozenges. Illicitly manufactured fentanyl (IMF) emerged in the 1970s but exploded in the 2010s, fueling the current opioid crisis.
description.uses: Medical: Prescribed as transdermal patches (Duragesic), lozenges (Actiq), or IV anesthesia for severe pain and surgical procedures. Cancer patients and chronic pain management. Illicitly: Added to heroin to increase potency, pressed into counterfeit pills (fake oxycodone, Xanax), or mixed into cocaine, meth, and MDMA as adulterant.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY HIGH OVERDOSE RISK: 2mg (size of few grains of salt) can be lethal. Respiratory depression occurs within seconds to minutes. Naloxone (Narcan) required immediately for overdose reversal—may need multiple doses. Increasingly found in non-opioid drugs causing unexpected overdoses. Analogues (carfentanil, acetylfentanyl) are even more potent. Cross-contamination during production endangers entire drug supply. Most overdose deaths now involve fentanyl. Test strips essential for any street drugs.

scientific_papers.title: Fentanyl and fentanyl analogues: 50 years on
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of fentanyl history, pharmacology, and role in current overdose crisis

scientific_papers.title: Evidence of fentanyl contamination in the unregulated drug supply
scientific_papers.summary: Study documenting widespread fentanyl contamination in heroin and other street drugs

scientific_papers.title: Performance of fentanyl test strips for rapid assessment of fentanyl in drug samples
scientific_papers.summary: Validation study showing fentanyl test strips are effective harm reduction tool

scientific_papers.title: The changing opioid crisis: development, challenges and opportunities
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of how illicit fentanyl transformed the opioid epidemic and increased mortality

notes: CRITICAL: Use fentanyl test strips. Reagents are unreliable for fentanyl/analogues. Extremely potent—use PPE.

fentanyl_strips.summary: Immunoassay strips are the recommended method. Dissolve tiny sample and follow strip instructions.

description.overview: Heroin (diacetylmorphine) is a highly addictive semi-synthetic opioid derived from morphine, which comes from opium poppy plants. It produces intense euphoria, pain relief, and sedation, but carries extreme risks of addiction, overdose, and infectious disease transmission. The current street supply is heavily contaminated with fentanyl.
description.origins: Synthesized from morphine in 1874 by English chemist C.R. Alder Wright. Commercialized by Bayer pharmaceutical company in 1898 as a 'safer' morphine substitute and cough suppressant (tradename 'Heroin'). Quickly recognized as highly addictive and banned in most countries by the 1920s-30s. Illicit production now centered in Afghanistan, Mexico, and Southeast Asia.
description.uses: No current medical use in the United States (diamorphine still used medically in UK for severe pain). Historically used for pain, cough suppression, and as morphine substitute. Recreationally used for intense euphoria, pain relief, and escape. Routes: injection (IV), smoking, snorting. IV use carries highest overdose and infection risk.
description.dangers: Extremely high addiction potential—physical dependence develops rapidly. Overdose causes respiratory depression and death, especially with fentanyl contamination (now in majority of heroin supply). HIV, Hepatitis C transmission from shared needles. Collapsed veins, bacterial infections, abscesses from injection. Withdrawal is intensely uncomfortable but not typically fatal. Xylazine (tranq) increasingly found in supply, causes severe wounds and doesn't respond to naloxone. Unpredictable potency makes every dose potentially lethal. Naloxone and fentanyl test strips are life-saving harm reduction tools.

scientific_papers.title: Supervised injection facilities: a review of the evidence
scientific_papers.summary: Review showing supervised injection sites reduce overdose deaths and disease transmission without increasing drug use

scientific_papers.title: The effectiveness of opioid maintenance treatment in prison settings
scientific_papers.summary: Evidence for methadone/buprenorphine maintenance reducing overdose risk and recidivism

scientific_papers.title: Fentanyl-contaminated heroin and overdose: a review
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of fentanyl contamination in heroin supply and impact on overdose mortality

notes: CRITICAL: Always use fentanyl test strips. Heroin frequently contaminated with fentanyl/analogues.

fentanyl_strips.summary: Essential due to widespread fentanyl contamination. Test every batch.

description.overview: N,N-Dimethyltryptamine (DMT) is an extremely powerful, fast-acting psychedelic that produces intense visual and auditory hallucinations, often described as 'breakthrough' experiences to alternate dimensions or encounters with entities. Effects last only 5-15 minutes when smoked but are profoundly intense. Naturally occurs in many plants and trace amounts in human body.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1931 by Canadian chemist Richard Manske. Found in numerous plants used in South American shamanic ceremonies (ayahuasca brew contains DMT from Psychotria viridis). Modern Western use popularized by Terence McKenna's lectures in 1980s-90s. Known as 'the spirit molecule' from Rick Strassman's 1990s clinical research and subsequent book/documentary.
description.uses: Traditional: Ayahuasca ceremonies in South American indigenous cultures (DMT + MAOI from Banisteriopsis caapi vine). Modern: Brief but intense psychedelic experiences, spiritual exploration, entity contact reports. Research: Strassman's studies suggested potential for understanding consciousness. Recreational: 'Breakthrough' experiences, visual phenomena beyond other psychedelics. Typically smoked/vaporized for 5-15min effects or oral with MAOI for hours-long ayahuasca experience.
description.dangers: Overwhelming psychological intensity—can be terrifying for unprepared users. Risk of injury during experience due to complete dissociation from physical reality. Entities and alien landscapes can cause lasting existential confusion or fear. Extremely rapid onset (seconds) prevents gradual adaptation. Post-experience integration challenges. When used as ayahuasca (oral + MAOI), dangerous drug interactions: SSRIs, other antidepressants, stimulants, tyramine-rich foods can cause serotonin syndrome or hypertensive crisis. Pure DMT relatively safe physiologically but psychological impact profound. Not recommended for those with psychotic disorders or family history.

notes: Ehrlich confirms indole. DMT usually yellowish crystals; pure is white.

scientific_papers.title: DMT: The Spirit Molecule - A Doctor's Revolutionary Research
scientific_papers.summary: Groundbreaking clinical research on DMT effects in human volunteers, documenting entity encounters and mystical experiences

scientific_papers.title: Human psychopharmacology of N,N-dimethyltryptamine
scientific_papers.summary: First modern controlled study of DMT in humans, pharmacokinetics and dose-response relationships

scientific_papers.title: DMT models the near-death experience
scientific_papers.summary: Study showing DMT experiences phenomenologically similar to near-death experiences

description.overview: 5-Methoxy-N,N-Dimethyltryptamine (5-MeO-DMT) is an extremely potent, fast-acting psychedelic tryptamine distinct from DMT. Produces intense ego dissolution, unity experiences, and 'white light' phenomena rather than DMT's colorful visuals and entities. Naturally found in various plants and Colorado River toad (Bufo alvarius) venom. Effects last 15-45 minutes but feel timeless. Considered one of the most powerful psychedelics.
description.origins: Isolated from plant sources in 1936. Found in Bufo alvarius (Sonoran Desert toad) venom in 1965. Synthetic version available. Traditional use by indigenous South American tribes in yopo snuff (Anadenanthera). Modern use popularized by ethnobotanist Jonathan Ott and later by 'toad smoking' phenomenon. Not as culturally widespread as DMT or ayahuasca. Recently scheduled in many countries but research ongoing.
description.uses: Traditional: Yopo snuff ceremonies. Modern: Ego death experiences, mystical/spiritual exploration, therapeutic potential for trauma/addiction. Some report life-changing realizations and healing. Effects: Complete dissolution of self, unity with universe, 'white light,' profound peace or terror depending on set/setting. Minimal visuals compared to DMT—more about internal experience. Duration 15-45 minutes when smoked/vaporized. Typical dose 5-20mg (extremely potent). Sometimes used in therapeutic contexts but requires experienced facilitation.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY INTENSE—overwhelming even for experienced psychedelic users. Can be terrifying if unprepared—complete ego death with no frame of reference. Risk of physical injury during experience (thrashing, falling). Should never be used standing or near hazards. Respiratory depression possible at high doses or combinations. Dangerous with MAOIs (serotonin syndrome, hypertensive crisis). Toad venom harvesting harms endangered species—synthetic preferred. Very difficult to distinguish from DMT by appearance—lab testing recommended. Psychological integration challenges post-experience. Can trigger lasting existential crisis or spiritual emergency. Contraindicated for heart conditions (cardiovascular stress). Not for recreational use—requires serious intention and safe setting. Reports of deaths from improper use or combinations.

notes: Very potent. Often confused with DMT. Reagent differentiation difficult—lab testing recommended.

description.overview: 5-MeO-DiPT (5-methoxy-N,N-diisopropyltryptamine, Foxy, Foxy Methoxy) is a psychedelic tryptamine with unique effects profile. More tactile/sensory than visual. Known for strong aphrodisiac effects and body sensations. Duration 3-6 hours. Popular in early 2000s rave/party scene. Less common now but still encountered.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in TiHKAL 1997. Became popular party drug early 2000s, especially in Japan. Known for sexual/tactile enhancement. Emergency scheduled in US 2004, other countries followed. Peak use 2000-2005. Now less common than peak but still available as RC. Nostalgic significance for those from early 2000s rave scene.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Tactile enhancement, body euphoria, mild visuals, aphrodisiac effects, empathogenic qualities. Typical dose 6-12mg oral, 3-6mg insufflated. Duration 3-6 hours. Popular at raves, parties, intimate settings for sexual/sensory enhancement. Less 'headspace' than classical psychedelics. Some users find it uniquely pleasurable; others experience uncomfortable body sensations.
description.dangers: Nausea very common, especially at higher doses. Uncomfortable body sensations ('weird feeling'). Can cause difficult trips despite less visual intensity. Dosing tricky—small increases cause major effects changes. Some users report lasting sexual dysfunction after use (unverified). Vasoconstriction. Insomnia. Can trigger anxiety, paranoia. Less studied than classical tryptamines—long-term effects unknown. Cross-tolerance with other tryptamines.

scientific_papers.title: 5-MeO-DiPT (Foxy): Pharmacology and subjective effects
scientific_papers.summary: Original documentation of 5-MeO-DiPT synthesis and effects

notes: Foxy, Foxy Methoxy. Known for tactile/sexual enhancement more than visuals. Ehrlich purple (tryptamine) but cannot distinguish from other tryptamines. Duration 3-6 hours. Nausea very common. Popular in early 2000s rave scene. Dose-sensitive. Unique effects profile—not like classical psychedelics. Less headspace, more body sensations.

description.overview: 2,5-Dimethoxy-4-(n)-propylthiophenethylamine (2C-T-7, Blue Mystic) is a potent psychedelic from Shulgin's 2C-T-x series. Documented in PiHKAL #30. Known for long duration (8-15 hours), intense visuals, and significant body load. Several deaths reported in early 2000s led to emergency scheduling. More dangerous than other 2C-x compounds.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin and documented in PiHKAL #30. Part of the 2C-T-x series (sulfur-containing 2C compounds). Appeared on research chemical market late 1990s-early 2000s. Gained reputation as intense, long-lasting alternative to 2C-B. Multiple deaths in 2000-2002 from overdoses and dangerous ROAs (insufflation particularly deadly). Emergency scheduled in 2003. Less common after scheduling but still occasionally appears.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense visual hallucinations, altered perception, psychedelic headspace. Typical oral dose 10-30mg. Duration 8-15 hours (very long). Shulgin described strong visuals and body effects. Popular briefly in early 2000s rave scene. Insufflation (snorting) was used by some but proved extremely dangerous—several deaths. Effects described as more 'earthy' and 'alien' than 2C-B. Strong empathogenic qualities at lower doses.
description.dangers: MULTIPLE DEATHS REPORTED: More dangerous than other 2C-x compounds. Insufflation (snorting) particularly deadly—causes rapid absorption, overwhelming effects, death. Oral use also risky: narrow dose-response curve, small dosing errors cause severe effects. Very long duration (8-15+ hours) makes bad trips prolonged ordeals. Significant body load: nausea, muscle tension, vasoconstriction. Slow onset (2-3 hours) causes dangerous redosing. Can cause seizures, hyperthermia, cardiovascular stress. Often mis-dosed in research chemical market. Deaths led to 2003 emergency scheduling. Contraindicated with heart conditions. Never insufflate—deaths occur.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-T-7: Blue Mystic psychedelic effects
scientific_papers.summary: PiHKAL #30 documentation of 2C-T-7 synthesis, 10-30mg dosage, 8-15 hour duration

scientific_papers.title: Deaths involving 2C-T-7: insufflation toxicity
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports showing insufflation of 2C-T-7 is extremely dangerous and often fatal

notes: DANGEROUS: Multiple deaths. NEVER insufflate (snort)—deadly. Long duration (8-15 hours). Dose 10-30mg oral only. PiHKAL #30. Scheduled 2003.

description.overview: 2,5-Dimethoxy-4-bromoamphetamine (DOB) is a potent, long-acting psychedelic amphetamine with effects lasting 18-30 hours. Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin and documented in PiHKAL. Known for intense visual hallucinations, physical stimulation, and extreme dose-sensitivity. Often mis-sold as other substances due to long duration mimicking multiple redoses.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin in 1967 and documented in PiHKAL #62 as one of the most potent compounds in the book. Used occasionally in psychedelic research in the 1970s. Appeared on recreational market in 1990s-2000s, often sold on blotter (like LSD) or as other substances. Scheduled as Schedule I. Known for causing confusion due to extremely long duration—users think it's not working and redose.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Long-lasting psychedelic experiences with intense visuals, body load, and stimulation. Effects 18-30 hours. Shulgin rated it highly for visual phenomena. Typical dose 1-3mg (extremely dose-sensitive—500mcg difference matters). Often consumed unknowingly when sold as 2C-B, MDMA, or other substances. Very slow onset (3-5 hours) leads to dangerous redosing.
description.dangers: VERY DANGEROUS—extreme dose-sensitivity and duration. 1-3mg active range; small dosing errors cause severe overdose. Duration 18-30 hours makes bad trips nightmares lasting over a day. Slow onset (3-5 hours) causes users to redose, leading to overwhelming experiences. Intense vasoconstriction, increased heart rate/blood pressure, hyperthermia risk. Combining with stimulants extremely dangerous. Often mis-sold as shorter-acting substances. Physical stimulation prevents sleep for 24+ hours. Difficult to distinguish from other DOx compounds or NBOMes without lab testing. Shulgin warned about narrow dosing window. Can trigger psychosis, especially with sleep deprivation.

scientific_papers.title: DOB: A novel hallucinogenic amphetamine
scientific_papers.summary: Original synthesis and documentation by Shulgin, noting extreme potency and long duration

notes: LONG DURATION: 18-30 hours. Extremely dose-sensitive (1-3mg). Slow onset causes dangerous redosing. Often mis-sold. Lab testing recommended.

description.overview: DOC (2,5-dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine) is a psychedelic amphetamine with 12-24 hour duration. Most commonly encountered DOx compound. Very potent (1.5-3mg), highly stimulating, strong visuals. Often sold on blotter as 'LSD' but much longer-lasting. Popular in psychonaut communities but controversial due to extreme duration and stimulation.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin in 1970s, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Most popular of DOx series due to more 'balanced' profile than DOI/DOM. Common on research chemical markets 2000s-2010s. Frequently mis-sold as LSD on blotter—duration difference causes problems. Less intense than DOI but still very long. Emergency scheduled in many countries. Still encountered on blotter and as powder.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense psychedelic visuals, stimulation, altered thinking, long introspective experiences. Typical dose 1.5-3mg. Duration 12-24 hours. Used for spiritual/therapeutic exploration. Described as more 'clearheaded' than DOI, less body load than DOM. Still extremely long—requires full day+ commitment. Some users appreciate; others find duration exhausting.
description.dangers: VERY LONG DURATION: 12-24 hours of intense effects physically and mentally taxing. Vasoconstriction severe (numbness, cold extremities, muscle tension). Stimulation causes tachycardia, hypertension, insomnia for 24+ hours. Bad trips last entire day. Often mis-sold as LSD—users expect 8-12 hours get 20+ hours. Thought loops, anxiety, paranoia. Can trigger HPPD. Dangerous with MAOIs. Cross-tolerance with other psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: DOC and the DOx series: Pharmacology and toxicology
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of DOC as most prevalent DOx compound

notes: Most common DOx compound. 12-24 hour duration—NOT like LSD! Often sold on blotter as LSD but lasts much longer. Ehrlich negative (phenethylamine) helps distinguish from LSD. Very potent (1.5-3mg). Severe vasoconstriction and stimulation. More 'balanced' than DOI/DOM but still overwhelming for most. If you suspect DOC instead of LSD, prepare for 18+ hour experience.

description.overview: DOI (2,5-dimethoxy-4-iodoamphetamine) is a psychedelic amphetamine from the DOx family. Extremely long duration (16-30 hours), very potent (1-3mg active dose), and highly stimulating. Produces intense visual hallucinations, thought loops, and body load. Can be overwhelming due to long duration. Often sold on blotter tabs like LSD but MUCH longer-lasting.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin in 1970s, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Remained obscure research chemical until 2000s. Sometimes sold as LSD on blotter (dangerous due to extreme duration difference). Less common than DOB or DOC but still encountered. Known for being very long-lasting and stimulating. Popular in psychonaut communities but controversial due to difficult experiences from duration.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense psychedelic visuals, stimulation, altered thinking, music enhancement. Typical dose 1-3mg (very potent). Duration 16-30 hours (exhausting). Not recommended for beginners—extremely long commitment. Some users appreciate deep introspection; others find duration unbearable. Often used for spiritual/therapeutic exploration but requires full day commitment.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY LONG DURATION: 16-30 hours of intense effects can be mentally and physically exhausting. Difficult to sleep even after effects diminish. Vasoconstriction (numbness, cold extremities). Stimulation can cause anxiety, paranoia. Thought loops common. Physically demanding—dehydration, muscle tension. Bad trips last 20+ hours. Often mis-sold as LSD—users expecting 8-12 hours get 24+ hours. Can trigger HPPD. Cross-tolerance with other psychedelics. Dangerous if combined with MAOIs or other drugs.

scientific_papers.title: DOI and the DOx family: Pharmacology and neurotoxicity
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of DOI and related psychedelic amphetamines

notes: CRITICAL: 16-30 hour duration—NOT like LSD! Often sold on blotter as 'LSD' but lasts 2-3x longer. Ehrlich NO reaction (phenethylamine not indole) helps distinguish from LSD/indoles. Marquis dark grey/black. Very potent (1-3mg). Extremely stimulating with severe vasoconstriction. Not recommended—overwhelming duration for most users. If you suspect DOI instead of LSD, prepare for 24+ hour experience.

description.overview: DOM (2,5-dimethoxy-4-methylamphetamine, STP) is a psychedelic amphetamine with 14-20 hour duration. Less potent than DOI but still very long-lasting and stimulating. Known from 1960s counterculture. Produces strong visual effects and mental stimulation. Can be overwhelming due to duration and stimulant effects.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin 1963, documented in PiHKAL. Became infamous as 'STP' in late 1960s San Francisco (Serenity, Tranquility, Peace). Distributed at 1967 Summer of Love—many bad trips due to high doses and long duration. Media panic ensued. Became Schedule I 1970. Less common than in 60s but still encountered. Historical significance in psychedelic culture.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Psychedelic visuals, enhanced colors, mental stimulation, body euphoria. Typical dose 3-10mg. Duration 14-20 hours. Used for deep introspection, spiritual experiences. More 'body-oriented' than LSD according to some. Very stimulating—can cause restlessness. Popular in 1960s but now rare. Requires major time commitment.
description.dangers: Very long duration (14-20 hours) physically and mentally taxing. High doses (>10mg) can cause severe confusion, panic, psychosis. Stimulation causes tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction. Insomnia persists after trip. Bad trips extremely difficult due to duration. Historical overdoses in 1960s from street tabs dosed too high. Thought loops, anxiety. Often mis-sold as other substances. Cross-tolerance with other psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: DOM (STP): A psychedelic amphetamine with historical significance
scientific_papers.summary: Original documentation of DOM synthesis and effects

notes: STP. Historical psychedelic from 1960s Summer of Love. 14-20 hour duration—extremely long. Ehrlich negative (not an indole) helps distinguish from LSD. Very stimulating. Less potent than DOI (3-10mg vs 1-3mg) but still long-lasting. Rare nowadays but occasionally encountered. Orange/brown Marquis reaction. Not recommended for beginners due to duration and stimulation.

description.overview: Gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHB) is a CNS depressant that occurs naturally in the human body in trace amounts. As a drug, it produces euphoria, relaxation, and sociability at low doses, but has an extremely narrow margin between desired effects and overdose. Commonly known as a 'date rape drug' though most use is voluntary. Liquid form makes dosing dangerous.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1874, developed as an anesthetic in 1960s but abandoned due to side effects. Used by bodybuilders in 1980s for alleged growth hormone release and sleep enhancement. Became popular club drug in 1990s. Scheduled as Schedule I (illicit) in 2000 but Schedule III when prescribed as Xyrem for narcolepsy. Precursors GBL and 1,4-BD legal in many areas and convert to GHB in body.
description.uses: Medical: Xyrem (sodium oxybate) prescribed for narcolepsy with cataplexy. Rare use as anesthetic in some countries. Recreational: Euphoria, disinhibition, enhanced sociability and sexuality. Popular in club/rave scenes and 'chemsex' contexts. Bodybuilding: Claimed (unproven) benefits for muscle growth and recovery. Typical dose 1-2.5g but highly variable by concentration. Duration 1.5-3 hours.
description.dangers: EXTREME OVERDOSE RISK: Very narrow therapeutic window. Difference between desired effects and unconsciousness can be <1g. Sudden onset—conscious to unconscious in minutes. Respiratory depression, vomiting while unconscious (aspiration risk), seizures. No antidote—supportive care only. Combining with alcohol is extremely dangerous and often fatal. Physical dependence develops quickly with regular use. Withdrawal can be life-threatening (similar to alcohol). Liquid form makes accurate dosing nearly impossible. Concentration varies wildly between batches. Used in drug-facilitated sexual assault. Memory impairment and blackouts common. Chronic use linked to cognitive impairment. GBL and 1,4-BD (precursors) are even more dangerous due to unpredictable conversion rates.

scientific_papers.title: Gamma hydroxybutyrate: a new drug of abuse
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical review of GHB pharmacology, toxicity, and overdose management

scientific_papers.title: GHB withdrawal syndrome: a review
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of severe and potentially fatal GHB withdrawal syndrome

scientific_papers.title: Club drugs: methylenedioxymethamphetamine, flunitrazepam, ketamine hydrochloride, and gamma-hydroxybutyrate
scientific_papers.summary: Overview of club drugs including GHB's role in drug-facilitated sexual assault

notes: Standard reagents ineffective for GHB/GBL. Specialized tests exist but uncommon. Use extreme caution with dosing.

description.overview: Phencyclidine (PCP, angel dust) is a dissociative anesthetic developed in the 1950s but discontinued for human use due to severe psychological side effects. Produces dissociation, numbness, and at high doses, extreme agitation, violence, and psychosis. Notorious for unpredictable and dangerous behavior. Still used in veterinary medicine.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1926, developed as IV anesthetic (Sernyl) by Parke-Davis in 1950s. Human use discontinued in 1965 due to postoperative delirium and psychosis. Veterinary use continued until 1978. Became street drug in 1960s-70s, often misrepresented as THC, mescaline, or LSD. Less popular now than in 1970s-80s 'angel dust' era but still present in drug supply.
description.uses: No current legitimate medical use. Veterinary use discontinued. Illicitly used for dissociative effects, numbness, feeling of strength/invincibility. Sometimes unknowingly consumed when sold as other drugs. Can be smoked (often on mint, parsley), snorted, injected, or taken orally. Effects 4-6 hours (oral/snorted), 30min-1hour (smoked). Doses vary wildly due to illicit production.
description.dangers: Extremely unpredictable and dangerous. Notorious for violent, bizarre, self-destructive behavior. Superhuman strength feeling leads to severe injuries. Numbness prevents pain awareness—users have seriously injured themselves without realizing. Acute: Aggression, psychosis, seizures, hyperthermia, hypertensive crisis, coma, death. Chronic: Memory loss, speech difficulties, depression, suicidal ideation. Psychological addiction common. Horrible withdrawal. Can trigger lasting psychosis. Often found as adulterant in other drugs. Combining with other depressants extremely dangerous.

scientific_papers.title: Phencyclidine (PCP): a dangerous drug, but useful in schizophrenia research
scientific_papers.summary: Review of PCP's role in NMDA receptor research and schizophrenia models

scientific_papers.title: PCP intoxication: assessment of possible indicators
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical presentation and management of PCP intoxication

scientific_papers.title: Phencyclidine-induced psychosis
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of PCP-induced psychotic episodes and lasting psychiatric effects

notes: PCP shows limited reagent reactions. Often adulterant in other substances.

description.overview: Dextromethorphan (DXM) is an over-the-counter cough suppressant that produces dissociative and hallucinogenic effects at high doses. Found in many cough syrups and cold medications, it's one of the most accessible psychoactive substances. Effects are dose-dependent with distinct 'plateaus' of intensity, from mild euphoria to complete dissociation.
description.origins: Developed in the 1950s-60s as a safer, non-addictive alternative to codeine for cough suppression. FDA-approved and widely available OTC since 1958. Recreational use documented since the 1960s but became more popular in the 1990s-2000s with internet information sharing. Often extracted from cough syrups (cold water extraction) to avoid consuming harmful additives.
description.uses: Medical: Cough suppressant in cold/flu medications (Robitussin, NyQuil, Delsym). Typical therapeutic dose 15-30mg. Recreational: Dissociative effects, 'robo-tripping,' visual distortions, euphoria. Doses range from 100mg (first plateau) to 1500mg+ (fourth plateau, complete dissociation). Popular among teenagers due to legal accessibility. Some report antidepressant effects at low doses.
description.dangers: Serotonin syndrome risk, especially when combined with antidepressants (SSRIs, MAOIs). Respiratory depression at high doses. Nausea and vomiting common ('robo-itch'). Cough syrups contain dangerous additives: acetaminophen (liver damage), guaifenesin (nausea), antihistamines (dangerous combinations). Dissociation can lead to injury from falls or accidents. Tolerance develops rapidly with frequent use. Psychological addiction possible. Chronic abuse linked to brain lesions (Olney's lesions - debated). Some products contain high amounts of acetaminophen which can cause fatal liver failure at recreational DXM doses. Always check active ingredients carefully.

scientific_papers.title: Dextromethorphan: an overview of safety issues
scientific_papers.summary: Review of DXM abuse patterns, toxicity, and risks especially in adolescents

scientific_papers.title: Recreational dextromethorphan use and abuse
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical overview of DXM's dissociative effects and abuse potential

scientific_papers.title: Serotonin toxicity associated with the use of over-the-counter cough and cold medications
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports of serotonin syndrome from DXM combinations with antidepressants

notes: Commonly extracted from cough medicine. Reagent tests limited value due to additives.

description.overview: Mescaline is a naturally occurring psychedelic alkaloid found in peyote, San Pedro, and other cacti. One of the oldest known psychedelics, producing visual hallucinations, altered perception, and spiritual experiences similar to psilocybin and LSD but with a unique character. Effects last 10-12 hours with relatively gentle come-up and minimal body load compared to synthetic psychedelics.
description.origins: Used by indigenous peoples of Mexico and southwestern US for at least 5,700 years in religious ceremonies. Peyote central to Native American Church practices (legally protected for members). Isolated in 1897, synthesized in 1919. Studied by early psychedelic researchers in 1950s-60s. Aldous Huxley's 'The Doors of Perception' (1954) popularized mescaline experiences. Scheduled in 1970 but peyote use remains legal for Native American Church.
description.uses: Traditional: Sacred medicine in indigenous ceremonies, vision quests, healing rituals (peyote and San Pedro). Recreational: Visual hallucinations, introspection, nature connection, spiritual experiences. San Pedro cactus tea more common than peyote due to conservation concerns. Typical dose 200-400mg mescaline or equivalent cactus material. Duration 10-12 hours. Known for warm, empathogenic quality alongside psychedelic effects.
description.dangers: Physiologically very safe—no lethal dose established. Primary risks psychological: bad trips, anxiety, paranoia especially at high doses or unsafe settings. Nausea and vomiting common during come-up (traditional preparation includes purging as spiritual cleansing). Cactus preparations can cause more stomach discomfort than pure mescaline. Can trigger latent mental health conditions. Peyote endangered due to overharvesting—ethical concerns with non-traditional use. San Pedro more sustainable. Contraindicated with heart conditions (slight cardiovascular stimulation). Very long duration can be exhausting. Set and setting crucial. Legal status: mescaline Schedule I, but peyote legal for Native American Church, San Pedro often legal as ornamental cactus.

scientific_papers.title: Mescaline: a global history of the first psychedelic
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive history of mescaline's role in indigenous cultures and Western psychedelic research

scientific_papers.title: Pharmacology and phenomenology of the psychedelic experience produced by mescaline
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical study of mescaline's psychological effects and safety profile

scientific_papers.title: Peyote and mescaline: effects and potential therapeutic uses
scientific_papers.summary: Review of mescaline pharmacology, traditional use, and therapeutic potential

notes: Rare in powder form. Often substituted with other psychedelics. Lab testing recommended.

description.overview: 25I-NBOMe (2C-I-NBOMe) is a potent synthetic psychedelic from the NBOMe series, often sold as 'LSD' on blotter paper. Produces intense visual hallucinations and stimulation but is significantly more dangerous than LSD with numerous deaths reported. Distinctive bitter/metallic taste (LSD is tasteless) and causes severe tongue numbness. Active at sub-milligram doses, highly dose-sensitive with narrow safety margin.
description.origins: Synthesized in 2003 by chemist Ralf Heim at Free University of Berlin for serotonin receptor research. Never intended for human consumption. Appeared on recreational market around 2010 as 'legal LSD alternative' and frequently sold as actual LSD. Multiple deaths reported 2012-2015 led to emergency scheduling. Part of NBOMe series (25I, 25C, 25B) all with similar dangers.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense visual hallucinations, euphoria, stimulation. Often consumed unknowingly when sold as LSD. Typical dose 200-800mcg on blotter (appears identical to LSD blotter). Effects 6-10 hours. Some users sought NBOMe specifically for intense visuals, but deaths and unpredictability have reduced intentional use. Harm reduction communities strongly discourage NBOMe use and emphasize testing all 'LSD' with Ehrlich reagent.
description.dangers: MULTIPLE DEATHS REPORTED—can be fatal at doses barely above 'normal' recreational amounts. Causes severe vasoconstriction leading to seizures, hyperthermia, multi-organ failure, death. Significantly more dangerous than LSD, psilocybin, or mescaline. Bitter/metallic taste and tongue numbness are warning signs (LSD is tasteless and causes no numbness—only ink/paper taste). Ehrlich reagent shows NO reaction to NBOMes (LSD turns purple). Physical effects: increased heart rate and blood pressure to dangerous levels, risk of stroke/heart attack. Psychological: anxiety, paranoia, panic, bad trips. Some users have died from single 'common' doses. Unpredictable response between individuals. Often mis-sold as LSD putting unsuspecting users at risk. CRITICAL: If blotter tastes bitter or numbs tongue, SPIT IT OUT IMMEDIATELY.

scientific_papers.title: 25I-NBOMe: a potent and toxic new psychedelic substance
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports of NBOMe toxicity including deaths, seizures, and multi-organ failure

scientific_papers.title: NBOMes: a systematic review of fatalities
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review documenting deaths associated with NBOMe series psychedelics

scientific_papers.title: Misrepresentation of LSD as 25I-NBOMe
scientific_papers.summary: Study on NBOMes being sold as LSD and importance of reagent testing to prevent deaths

notes: DANGEROUS: Often mis-sold as LSD. Bitter/numbing taste. Can be fatal. Ehrlich test essential—LSD reacts, NBOMe does NOT.

description.overview: 25C-NBOMe (2C-C-NBOMe) is a potent synthetic psychedelic from the NBOMe series, similar to 25I-NBOMe but derived from 2C-C. Often sold as 'LSD' on blotter. Produces intense visuals and stimulation with significant dangers. Multiple deaths reported. Bitter/metallic taste and severe tongue numbness distinguish it from LSD. Active at sub-milligram doses.
description.origins: Synthesized in 2003 by Ralf Heim at Free University of Berlin for serotonin receptor research, never intended for human consumption. Appeared on research chemical market around 2010 alongside 25I-NBOMe as 'legal LSD alternative.' Multiple deaths 2012-2015 led to emergency scheduling. Part of NBOMe series (25I, 25C, 25B) all with similar dangers. Often mis-sold as LSD putting unsuspecting users at risk.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense visual hallucinations, stimulation, euphoria. Often consumed unknowingly when sold as LSD. Typical dose 400-800mcg on blotter. Effects 6-10 hours. Some users sought NBOMes specifically for intense visuals before deaths became widely known. Harm reduction communities strongly discourage all NBOMe use and emphasize testing all 'LSD' with Ehrlich reagent.
description.dangers: CAN BE FATAL—multiple deaths reported at doses barely above recreational amounts. Causes severe vasoconstriction leading to seizures, hyperthermia, multi-organ failure, death. Significantly more dangerous than LSD, psilocybin, or mescaline. Bitter/metallic taste and tongue numbness are warning signs (LSD is tasteless—only ink/paper taste). Ehrlich reagent shows NO reaction to NBOMes (LSD turns purple). Physical effects: dangerous increases in heart rate and blood pressure, stroke/heart attack risk. Psychological: anxiety, paranoia, panic, bad trips. Some users died from single 'common' doses. Unpredictable response between individuals. Often mis-sold as LSD. CRITICAL: If blotter tastes bitter or numbs tongue, SPIT IT OUT.

scientific_papers.title: NBOMes: pharmacology, toxicology, and deaths
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review documenting deaths associated with entire NBOMe series including 25C-NBOMe

notes: DANGEROUS: Often mis-sold as LSD. Bitter/numbing taste. Can be fatal. Ehrlich test essential—LSD reacts, NBOMe does NOT.

description.overview: 25B-NBOMe (2C-B-NBOMe) is a potent synthetic psychedelic from the NBOMe series, derived from 2C-B. Often sold as 'LSD' or '2C-B' on blotter. Produces intense visuals but with significant dangers. Multiple deaths reported. Bitter/metallic taste and severe tongue numbness. Active at sub-milligram doses. Less common than 25I or 25C but equally dangerous.
description.origins: Synthesized in 2003 by Ralf Heim for research, never intended for human use. Appeared on research chemical market around 2010-2011 as part of NBOMe series. Less popular than 25I-NBOMe but still caused deaths and hospitalizations. Emergency scheduled along with other NBOMes 2013-2016 depending on country. Often confused with actual 2C-B despite being much more dangerous.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense visual hallucinations, stimulation, sometimes sold as '2C-B' or 'LSD.' Typical dose 500-1000mcg. Effects 6-10 hours. Some users thought they were getting safer 2C-B but received dangerous NBOMe instead. Less sought-after than 25I-NBOMe but still appeared on blotter. Testing essential—cannot distinguish from LSD or 2C-B by appearance.
description.dangers: CAN BE FATAL—deaths reported though less common than 25I-NBOMe. Severe vasoconstriction, seizures, hyperthermia, cardiovascular stress. More dangerous than the 2C-B it's derived from. Bitter/metallic taste and tongue numbness (2C-B powder also bitter but NBOMe on blotter shouldn't be). Ehrlich shows NO reaction (differentiates from LSD). Unpredictable potency—deaths from doses thought to be safe. Often mis-sold as actual 2C-B or LSD. Physical effects dangerous: increased heart rate/BP, stroke risk. Psychological: anxiety, panic, bad trips. CRITICAL: Test all blotter with Ehrlich. If bitter on blotter, SPIT OUT.

scientific_papers.title: The NBOMe series: structure, toxicity, and fatalities
scientific_papers.summary: Review of NBOMe series including 25B-NBOMe, documenting toxicity and deaths

notes: DANGEROUS: Often mis-sold as 2C-B or LSD. Bitter/numbing taste on blotter. Can be fatal. Ehrlich test shows NO reaction (unlike LSD).

description.overview: Alprazolam (Xanax) is a fast-acting, potent benzodiazepine prescribed for anxiety and panic disorders. Produces relaxation, sedation, and anxiolytic (anti-anxiety) effects. One of the most prescribed and most abused benzos due to rapid onset and euphoric effects at higher doses. Street 'Xanax' pills frequently counterfeit and contain fentanyl, other benzos (flualprazolam, etizolam), or no active ingredient.
description.origins: Developed by Upjohn (now Pfizer) in late 1960s, FDA-approved 1981. Became one of most prescribed psychiatric medications in US. Short half-life (6-12 hours) makes it effective for acute anxiety but also increases addiction potential. Available in immediate-release tablets (0.25mg to 2mg) and extended-release (Xanax XR). 'Bars' (2mg) became street drug of choice in 2000s-2010s, often combined with opioids or alcohol.
description.uses: Medical: Anxiety disorders, panic disorder, anxiety associated with depression. Short-term use recommended due to tolerance and dependence. Rapid relief of acute anxiety/panic attacks. Recreational: Sedation, disinhibition, euphoria (at high doses), blackout experiences, combining with opioids or alcohol ('lean'). Popular in hip-hop culture. Pressed counterfeit pills widely available on street/dark web. Typical prescribed dose 0.25-2mg; recreational users often take 4-10mg+ leading to blackouts and dangerous behavior.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE—physical dependence develops within weeks. Withdrawal can be FATAL (seizures, delirium tremens)—requires medical supervision to safely discontinue. Blackouts and amnesia common at recreational doses leading to dangerous behavior, accidents, sexual assault. Combining with opioids or alcohol frequently FATAL (respiratory depression). Counterfeit 'Xanax' bars often contain fentanyl—numerous overdose deaths. Pressed pills may contain flualprazolam (longer-acting, more sedating RC benzo) or other research chemicals. Tolerance develops rapidly requiring higher doses. Cognitive impairment, motor coordination issues increase fall/accident risk. Paradoxical reactions possible (increased anxiety, aggression). Rebound anxiety when stopping. Elderly particularly vulnerable to falls, confusion, dementia-like symptoms. Reagent tests don't work on benzos—fentanyl test strips essential for any street pills.

scientific_papers.title: Alprazolam dependence and withdrawal: a review of the syndrome and treatment
scientific_papers.journal: Expert Opinion on Drug Metabolism & Toxicology
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of alprazolam's high addiction potential and withdrawal management

scientific_papers.title: The epidemiology of alprazolam misuse: a review
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of alprazolam abuse patterns, counterfeit pills, and overdose risks

scientific_papers.title: Counterfeit alprazolam tablets containing fentanyl: a new public health concern
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of fentanyl-contaminated fake Xanax pills and overdose deaths

notes: Xanax. Benzos do NOT react with colorimetric reagents. Many pressed 'Xanax' bars contain fentanyl or RC benzos—use fentanyl strips.

fentanyl_strips.summary: CRITICAL for pressed pills. Many fake Xanax bars contain fentanyl.

description.overview: Bromo-DragonFLY (DOB-DragonFLY) is an extremely potent and dangerous synthetic psychedelic with an extraordinarily long duration of 18-36+ hours. Named for its molecular structure resembling a dragonfly, it has been responsible for multiple deaths due to overdose, extreme vasoconstriction, and being mis-sold as other substances. Active in sub-milligram doses with a very narrow safety margin.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1998 by Matthew Parker at Purdue University as part of research on serotonin receptor binding. Never intended for human consumption. Appeared on the recreational market in the mid-2000s, often mis-sold as 2C-B-FLY or LSD. Multiple deaths and severe injuries in 2008-2009 led to emergency scheduling in many countries. Remains available but rare.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense, extremely long-lasting psychedelic experiences. Effects can persist 24-36 hours or longer. Some users sought it for its unique visual and mental effects, but extreme duration, narrow dosing window, and severe dangers have made it highly discouraged by harm reduction communities. Often consumed unknowingly when sold as safer substances.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS—multiple deaths and serious injuries reported. Causes severe vasoconstriction leading to tissue necrosis, limb amputation, seizures, hyperthermia, and death. Duration of 18-36+ hours makes bad trips prolonged nightmares. Extremely dose-sensitive: difference between threshold and dangerous dose is tiny (200-800mcg range). Often mis-sold as 2C-B-FLY, LSD, or other psychedelics. Onset can take 2-6 hours, leading users to redose and overdose fatally. Physiological effects include extreme vasoconstriction, tissue damage, potential organ failure. Psychological effects: terror, confusion, psychosis lasting days. No antidote. Medical intervention may be required for days. Considered one of the most dangerous research chemicals. AVOID—multiple safer alternatives exist.

scientific_papers.title: Bromo-dragonFLY: a case report of a new psychoactive substance
scientific_papers.summary: Case report documenting severe toxicity including seizures and prolonged effects from Bromo-DragonFLY

scientific_papers.title: Severe toxicity following Bromo-DragonFLY intoxication
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of multiple Bromo-DragonFLY poisonings including deaths and amputations

notes: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS: Multiple deaths. Extreme vasoconstriction, 18-36+ hour duration. Often mis-sold. AVOID. Reagent tests cannot distinguish from 2C-B-FLY.

description.overview: Clonazepam (Klonopin) is a long-acting benzodiazepine prescribed for anxiety, panic disorder, and seizures. Duration 6-12 hours, long half-life (30-40 hours) means effects accumulate. More potent than diazepam. High abuse potential. Widely prescribed and frequently diverted. Known for causing severe dependence and difficult withdrawal.
