description.overview: NEP (N-Ethylpentedrone) is a synthetic cathinone stimulant. Similar to pentedrone and other cathinones. Produces stimulation, euphoria, increased energy. Shorter duration than amphetamines (2-4 hours). Research chemical with minimal safety data. Addictive - compulsive redosing common. Legal status varies—often sold as 'research chemical' or 'not for human consumption.'
description.origins: Developed as research chemical 2010s. Part of synthetic cathinone wave after mephedrone bans. Little known use before 2015. Sold online as legal alternative to banned cathinones. Minimal scientific research. Potency and effects vary batch-to-batch. Banned in many countries under blanket cathinone/analogue laws.
description.uses: Recreational: Stimulation, euphoria, increased energy and focus, sociability. Typical dose 30-100mg insufflated or oral. Duration 2-4 hours. Often redosed compulsively. Used as alternative to cocaine, meth, or other cathinones. Some use for productivity (not recommended—unsafe).
description.dangers: Highly addictive - compulsive redosing leads to binges. Cardiovascular strain: tachycardia, hypertension, chest pain. Hyperthermia, dehydration. Anxiety, paranoia, psychosis (especially with binging). Severe vasoconstriction. Neurotoxicity unknown but likely similar to other cathinones. Crash/comedown: depression, fatigue, anhedonia. Long-term effects completely unknown—no human safety studies. Quality varies—adulterants possible. Legal risks.

notes: N-Ethylpentedrone. Synthetic cathinone stimulant. Highly addictive—compulsive redosing. Duration 2-4 hours. Orange Marquis (cathinone). NO human safety data. Cardiovascular risks, paranoia, psychosis. Quality varies. Legal status unclear. Research chemical—extreme caution.

description.overview: Hexen (N-Ethylhexedrone) is a synthetic cathinone stimulant. More potent than NEP. Short duration (1-3 hours) leading to compulsive redosing. Produces stimulation, euphoria, focus. Research chemical with no safety data. Highly addictive. Infamous for terrible smell (described as cum/semen). Legal status varies—often sold as research chemical.
description.origins: Appeared on RC markets mid-2010s. Became popular briefly as legal stimulant alternative. Notorious for awful smell/taste. Many users report extreme compulsive redosing. Minimal scientific study. Banned in many jurisdictions under cathinone/analogue laws. Still available from RC vendors in some countries.
description.uses: Recreational: Strong stimulation, euphoria, focus, sociability. Typical dose 40-120mg insufflated/oral. Duration 1-3 hours (very short—encourages redosing). Used as cocaine/meth alternative. Some attempt productivity use (very risky). Insufflation causes intense burning.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE: Compulsive redosing nearly unavoidable for most users. Very short duration drives binges. Severe cardiovascular strain: tachycardia, chest pain, hypertension. Hyperthermia. Extreme vasoconstriction (cold extremities, potential tissue damage). Paranoia, anxiety, psychosis common. Terrible comedown: depression, exhaustion, anhedonia. Awful smell/taste (described as semen—lingers on skin/breath). NO safety data. Neurotoxicity likely. Legal risks.

notes: N-Ethylhexedrone. Cathinone. EXTREMELY addictive—compulsive redosing. Duration 1-3 hours (very short). Orange Marquis. Infamous for terrible smell (cum/semen). Severe cardiovascular risks, paranoia. NO safety data. Avoid—many users regret trying. Research chemical.

description.overview: 3-FEA (3-Fluoroethamphetamine) is a fluorinated amphetamine with empathogenic and stimulant effects. Described as milder than MDMA but similar profile. Duration 4-6 hours. Research chemical with limited human data. Less neurotoxic than MDMA (possibly) but still carries risks. Legal status varies—often sold as research chemical.
description.origins: Synthesized as research chemical 2010s. Gained popularity as MDMA alternative when cathinones started getting banned. Part of fluorinated amphetamine series (2-FA, 3-FA, 4-FA, etc.). Each has different effects profile. 3-FEA specifically known for empathogenic effects. Minimal scientific research. Some countries ban all fluorinated amphetamines.
description.uses: Recreational: Empathy, emotional openness, mild euphoria, stimulation, music enhancement. Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 4-6 hours. Used as MDMA substitute—less intense but similar vibe. Some use for social situations, raves, concerts. Described as gentler, less overwhelming than MDMA.
description.dangers: Neurotoxicity unknown—possibly less than MDMA but unproven. Serotonin depletion possible. Cardiovascular strain: tachycardia, hypertension. Hyperthermia risk (like MDMA). Jaw clenching, nystagmus. Combining with SSRIs/MAOIs risky (serotonin syndrome). Comedown/aftereffects: depression, fatigue. NO long-term safety data. Fluorinated amphetamines understudied. Quality/purity varies. Legal risks.

notes: 3-Fluoroethamphetamine. Empathogen-stimulant. MDMA-like but milder. Duration 4-6 hours. Orange Marquis. Neurotoxicity unknown. Serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs/MAOIs. NO long-term safety data. Research chemical. Quality varies.

description.overview: A-PHP (α-Pyrrolidinohexiophenone) is a synthetic cathinone from the pyrovalerone family (same as α-PVP/flakka). EXTREMELY potent and addictive. Very short duration (30 minutes-2 hours) causing compulsive redosing. Severe paranoia and psychosis common. Often vaped. One of most dangerous cathinones. Many horror stories.
description.origins: Appeared on RC markets mid-2010s after α-PVP (flakka) bans. Chemically very similar to α-PVP. Quickly gained reputation as extremely addictive and dangerous. Many trip reports describe psychotic episodes, paranoia, dangerous behavior. Banned in many countries. Still available from RC vendors in some regions.
description.uses: Recreational: Intense stimulation, euphoria (short-lived). Typical dose 5-30mg (very potent). Duration 30min-2hrs. Often vaped for faster onset. Compulsive redosing nearly universal. Described as more euphoric than α-PVP but equally dangerous.
description.dangers: EXTREME ADDICTION POTENTIAL: Compulsive redosing leads to multi-day binges. SEVERE PSYCHOSIS common: paranoia, hallucinations, delusions, violent behavior. Cardiovascular crisis: tachycardia, chest pain, heart attack. Hyperthermia. Extreme vasoconstriction. 'Stim dick' (erectile dysfunction). Insomnia for days. Terrible comedown: suicidal depression, exhaustion. Many users report regretting ever trying. Hospitalization/arrest common. NO safety data. Avoid.

notes: α-Pyrrolidinohexiophenone. Pyrovalerone cathinone like flakka. EXTREME DANGER: Highly addictive, severe psychosis common. Duration 30min-2hrs. Orange Marquis. Compulsive redosing, paranoia, violent behavior reported. Many regret trying. AVOID. Research chemical.

description.overview: Memantine (Namenda) is an NMDA receptor antagonist prescribed for Alzheimer's disease. At recreational doses (50-150mg+), produces dissociative effects similar to DXM or ketamine but much longer duration (12-24+ hours). Effects described as clearer, less confusing than DXM. Some use for harm reduction (tolerance reduction to other substances). Relatively safe at therapeutic doses.
description.origins: Synthesized 1963. Approved for Alzheimer's 2003 in US. Discovered by psychonauts 2000s-2010s to have dissociative effects at higher doses. Less well-known than DXM or ketamine but has dedicated following. Legal—available by prescription. Some obtain for off-label use (tolerance reduction, nootropic, recreational). Slow onset discourages abuse.
description.uses: Medical: Alzheimer's disease (10-20mg daily). Recreational/off-label: Dissociation (50-150mg), tolerance reduction to stimulants/opioids, nootropic (low doses). Duration 12-24+ hours (very long). Slow onset (2-4 hours). Effects: dissociation, altered perception, mild euphoria, reduced anxiety. Described as clearer and more functional than DXM.
description.dangers: Very long duration can be uncomfortable if dose too high (stuck dissociated for day). Cognitive impairment while active. Motor incoordination. Dizziness. At high doses: confusion, memory impairment, hallucinations. Can worsen mental health issues. Interactions with other drugs possible. Relatively safe compared to other dissociatives but still carries risks. Not recommended for frequent recreational use.

notes: Namenda. NMDA antagonist dissociative. Alzheimer's medication. Duration 12-24+ hours (VERY long). Higher doses (50-150mg) cause dissociation. Clearer than DXM. Used for tolerance reduction. Relatively safe but long duration can be uncomfortable. Prescription medication. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Baclofen is a GABA-B receptor agonist prescribed for muscle spasticity, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injuries. Similar mechanism to phenibut and GHB. At higher doses, produces sedation, euphoria, alcohol-like intoxication. Increasing recreational abuse. Physical dependence develops quickly. Withdrawal can be severe including hallucinations and seizures. Prescription medication—Schedule not controlled in US but regulated.
description.origins: Synthesized 1962. Approved for medical use 1977. Used for muscle spasticity, MS, spinal injuries, cerebral palsy. Researched for alcohol/GHB addiction treatment (high-dose baclofen therapy). Recreational abuse emerged 2000s-2010s, especially among opioid users and in prison populations. Awareness of abuse potential increasing.
description.uses: Medical: Muscle spasticity (10-80mg/day divided doses), MS, spinal cord injury. Off-label/research: Alcohol addiction treatment (up to 300mg/day under supervision). Recreational: Euphoria, sedation, anxiolysis, alcohol-like intoxication. Typical recreational dose 75-150mg+. Duration 4-8 hours. Used by some as GHB/phenibut alternative.
description.dangers: PHYSICAL DEPENDENCE develops quickly with daily use. SEVERE WITHDRAWAL: hallucinations, seizures, delirium, psychosis—can be life-threatening. Requires slow medical taper (like benzos/alcohol). Overdose causes severe CNS depression, respiratory depression, coma. FATAL when combined with other depressants (alcohol, opioids, benzos). Cognitive impairment, memory issues. Motor incoordination. Can worsen mental health conditions. High-dose therapy requires medical supervision.

scientific_papers.title: Baclofen withdrawal: Case reports and review
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of severe baclofen withdrawal syndrome

notes: GABA-B agonist muscle relaxant. Similar to phenibut/GHB. Physical dependence develops quickly. SEVERE WITHDRAWAL—hallucinations, seizures, can be FATAL. Requires medical taper. Often FATAL with alcohol/opioids/benzos. Prescription medication. Recreational abuse increasing. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is a tropical tree native to Southeast Asia whose leaves contain alkaloids that act as opioid agonists and stimulants. At low doses, produces stimulant effects; at higher doses, opioid-like pain relief and sedation. Widely used for pain management, opioid withdrawal, and energy. Legal status varies by country and US state.
description.origins: Used traditionally in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia for centuries by laborers to combat fatigue and manage pain. Leaves chewed fresh or brewed as tea. Western awareness grew in 1800s but remained obscure until 2000s internet commerce. Banned in Thailand (ironically, its origin) since 1943 but recently re-legalized. DEA attempted scheduling in 2016 but withdrew after public outcry. Currently unscheduled federally in US but banned in several states.
description.uses: Traditional: Energy, pain relief, treating diarrhea, wound healing. Modern: Self-treatment for chronic pain (alternative to prescription opioids), opioid withdrawal aid (reduces symptoms), anxiety and depression relief, energy and focus (low doses), recreational sedation (high doses). Strains: Red (sedating, pain relief), Green (balanced), White (energizing). Typical dose 2-5g (moderate) to 5-10g+ (strong). Often consumed as powder in capsules, 'toss and wash,' or tea.
description.dangers: Physical dependence and withdrawal with regular use—symptoms similar to mild opioid withdrawal (muscle aches, irritability, insomnia, runny nose). Tolerance develops, requiring increasing doses. Nausea and 'wobbles' (dizziness, nausea) common at high doses or with certain strains. Constipation (opioid effect). Liver toxicity rare but reported with chronic heavy use or adulterated products. Respiratory depression possible when combined with other CNS depressants (alcohol, benzos, opioids)—deaths almost always involve poly-drug use. Seizures reported in rare cases. Quality control issues: products may be contaminated with salmonella, heavy metals, or adulterated with actual opioids. Some extracts (shots, enhanced products) extremely potent. Addiction potential debated but real for some users. Can test positive for methadone on some drug tests (false positive).

scientific_papers.title: Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa): User motivations, use patterns and implications for use disorder
scientific_papers.summary: Large survey study on kratom use patterns, self-reported benefits, and dependence potential

scientific_papers.title: Pharmacology of kratom: An emerging botanical agent with stimulant, analgesic and opioid-like effects
scientific_papers.journal: Journal of the American Osteopathic Association
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of kratom alkaloids, pharmacology, mechanisms, and clinical effects

scientific_papers.title: Kratom and Pain: Reviewing the Evidence
scientific_papers.summary: Review of kratom's analgesic properties and potential for opioid withdrawal management

scientific_papers.title: Kratom dependence and withdrawal: A case series
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical case reports documenting kratom withdrawal syndrome in chronic users

notes: Mitragyna speciosa. Contains mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine (opioid agonists). Reagent testing limited for plant material—mainly confirms not synthetic opioid.
